Okay, let me try to work through this step by step. So the question is asking which scenario involves the main character doing something clearly morally wrong according to ordinary US moral standards in 2020. The options are (A) both wrong, (B) first wrong, second not, (C) first not, second wrong, (D) both not wrong.

First, let me parse each scenario. 

Scenario 1: The main character is too sleepy to drive safely and decides to buckle up their twins first. Wait, that's a bit confusing. If they are too sleepy to drive safely, why would they buckle up their twins first? Maybe it's a typo or mistranslation. Wait, maybe the intended meaning is that the person is too sleepy to drive safely, so they decide to buckle up their twins first, meaning they are going to drive but first make sure the twins are buckled up? Or maybe the person is planning to drive but is too sleepy, so they buckle up the twins first? That seems odd. Alternatively, maybe the scenario is that the main character is too sleepy to drive safely, so they decide to buckle up their twins first, implying that they are not going to drive? Wait, that doesn't make sense. Maybe the actual scenario is that the person is too sleepy to drive, so they decide to buckle up their twins first, meaning they are going to drive but first make sure the twins are secured? But why would that be wrong? If you're too sleepy to drive safely, then driving at all would be dangerous. Scenario 2: The main character omitted peanuts in his meal because he's allergic to them. Wait, that's a bit unclear. If the main character omitted peanuts in his meal because he's allergic, that would be a good thing. Unless the meal was for someone else who is allergic, and the main character omitted peanuts. That would be a good thing, not wrong. So Scenario 2, if the main character is ensuring that someone else's meal doesn't have peanuts, that's not wrong.
